person.note: Robert Graves' eldest son by Beryl William Graves (282) was born on July 1940. Geologist. Literary Executor of the Robert Graves Estate, Setlor of the Robert Graves Copyright Trust and the St John’s College Robert Graves Trust; founder member of the Fundacio Robert Graves in Mallorca which owns Robert Graves’s house. Author of Wild Olives. In 1965, he married Elena Lambea b. July 1941.

Robert von Ranke Graves (248) was born 24 July 1895 in Wimbledon, London, England, and died 7 Dec. 1985 in Deya, Majorca. He was Capt. RWF and a renowned poet, novelist, mythographer, critic and historian. Probably best known as the author of I,Claudius, and Claudius the God and as a survivor and poet of the Great War, he is one of the great figures of 20th Century English Poetry. He first married Annie Mary Prydie ("Nancy") Nicholson, daughter of William Nicholson, the artist, on 23 Jan. 1918 in St. James, Piccadilly. She was born 13 Sept. 1899 and died in 1977. Nancy refused to change her name on marriage and insisted the girls born of the union keep her surname. He then married Beryl née Prichard, (divorced from Hodge and who changed her name by deed-pole to Graves on 25 June 1943), on 12 May 1950, at the British Consulate in Palma. She was born 22 Feb 1915 and died 27 October 2003.

Robert Graves's second wife. PPE at St Anne's College, Oxford. Married Alan Hodge 1938. Changed her name by deed poll from Hodge to Graves in June 1943. Married Robert Graves on 12 May 1950, at the British Consulate in Palma, after his divorce from Nancy Nicholson earlier that year.

person.note: He was born Karl Goldschmidt in Germany, in 1912. He trained as a graphic artist but left his native country in 1933 on Hitler's rise to power. 1934 found him in Dey, Majorca, where the poets Robert Graves and Laura Riding befriended the intelligent young man. He learnt English (reading Defoe) and was soon helping with their Seizin Press and their typing, and wrote amusingly in Focus, their magazine. At the outbreak of the Spanish Civil War in 1936, all three left Majorca on a Royal Navy destroyer. Graves persuaded the ship's captain not to transfer Goldschmidt to a German ship, and back to Germany, conscious of the fate that would, as a Jew, await him. In England Goldschmidt obtained leave to stay and work and, when the Second World War broke out, he gallantly served first in the Pioneer Corps, and later in the Royal Navy. In the Pioneers - as a protection in case of capture - he had been made to change his name. He became known (though he was always called Karl by his friends) as Kenneth Gay. When the war was over, he was granted full British citizenship.
